summary:
The Security Council,

Adopted resolution 2058 (2012) on 19 July 2012, 

Welcoming the report of the Secretary-General on UN operation in Cyprus, 

Noting the necessity to keep UNFICYP in Cyprus beyond 19 July 2012, 

Echoing the Secretary-General’s belief that finding a solution lies primarily with the Cypriots, 

Reaffirming the UN's primary role in assisting parties to achieve a comprehensive and durable settlement, 

Welcoming progress in negotiations and leaders’ joint statements, 

Recalling the importance of full, flexible and constructive engagement in negotiations, 

Welcoming efforts to stimulate progress and supporting continued efforts, 

Noting the need to advance military confidence building measures and implement remaining measures, 

Reaffirming the importance of Green Line crossings and encouraging opening of other crossing points, 

Convinced of benefits of a comprehensive Cyprus settlement, 

Urging leaders to foster positive public rhetoric and explain settlement benefits, 

Highlighting the international community's supporting role, 

Taking note of the stable security situation, 

Recalling the 1989 aide-memoire and need for demining, 

Highlighting the Committee on Missing Persons' activities, 

Agreeing on the essential role of civil society groups, 

Stressing the need for a rigorous approach to peacekeeping deployments, 

Welcoming the Secretary-General's intention to review peacekeeping operations.
Here is a summarized version of the Security Council document:

The Security Council:

Welcomes efforts of Alexander Downer and Lisa Buttenheim in assisting parties in negotiations for a comprehensive settlement in Cyprus.

1. Acknowledges progress in negotiations but notes it's insufficient, urging parties to continue discussions to reach decisive progress on core issues.

2. Takes note of the Secretary-General's report (S/2012/507).

3. Recalls resolution 2026 (2011) and calls on leaders to:
    (a) Work on convergences on core issues;
    (b) Work with Technical Committees to improve daily lives of Cypriots;
    (c) Improve public atmosphere and deliver constructive messages;
    (d) Increase civil society participation.

4. Urges implementation of confidence-building measures, including military measures and opening of crossing points.

5. Urges parties to accommodate Committee for Missing Persons exhumation requirements.

6. Reaffirms relevant resolutions, particularly resolution 1251 (1999).
